Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Analyzing Spaces and Scalar Fields via Point Clouds

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent advances in scanning technology and general progress in science and engineering have made it easy to sample a geometry presented explicitly or implicitly. In some cases, sampling allows the data to be equipped with values of a scalar function defined on the sampled domain. The goal is to process the resulting point cloud data (PCD) for approximating different geometric and topological structures of the original space and/or functions defined on them. How can this be achieved is the main agenda of this award.

The extraction of geometric and topological structures from a PCD begins with the understanding of these structures on the original sampled space. In some cases one needs to adapt existing mathematical concepts to fit the discretization inherent in algorithmic development. In others new analysis techniques and new algorithmic tools need to be developed. PIs expect the more of the latter to tame the curse of dimensionality and scale. The two PIs bring their expertise in computational geometry and computational topology to the board to conduct the project.

A central problem in data analysis is to design computational methods for representing and retrieving information from massive and high-dimensional data. Various scientific, engineering, and social studies such as the ones in product development, medicine, economics, climate, disease control produce data that presumably sample a hidden parameter space sitting in a high dimension. They will benefit from the techniques developed in this project. By the very nature of the problems, this project will enhance a synergy between fields such as mathematics, theoretical computer science, and data analysis.

Other than standard research forums, results from the project will be disseminated through course notes, tutorials, and web-pages to reach wider audience. Graduate students supported by the project will develop skills in mathematics and theoretical computer science, most notably in geometry and topology and also in writing robust, efficient and user-friendly software.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In many applications in science and engineering, we are given data in the form of a discrete set of points approximating a hidden domain. For example, molecular simulations can produce a set of protein conformations, each of which can be represented as a high-dimensional point, sampled from the conformational space of that molecule. An input point cloud data (PCD) can also be equipped with scalar values (for example each protein conformation can be associated with its potential energy). The goal of this project was to develop effective and efficient algorithms to extract different geometric and topological structures from a discrete point sample of a hidden space, or scalar functions defined on such a space.

PI Dey and co-PI Wang collaborated closely throughout the course of this project. They specifically focused on taming the curse of scale and noise that often accompany real data. In particular, it has been demonstrated that the persistent homology can be a powerful tool in characterizing and summarizing a space or a function. The PIs studied persistent homology induced by the so-called simplicial maps, which is more general, and also can be more space-efficient in describing a filtration, than the traditional persistent homology induced by inclusion maps. Together with their students and collaborators, they proposed the notion of ``annotation" and developed efficient algorithms to compute the persistent homology induced by a sequence of simplicial maps. This further helped them to develop a subsampling approach, called ``graph induced complex", to decipher  topological features from discrete samples using a filtered complex of orders-of-magnitude smaller size than what has been used traditionally.  

The PIs also tackled the important problem of handling noise in data. They provided theoretical understanding of how the commonly used Gaussian-weighted graph Laplacian behaves on PCDs sampled from a noisy manifold. Together with collaborators, they also presented a new noise model that captures both geometric and functional noise in data, as well as an algorithm to recover topological features of a scalar field from noisy input.

The results of this project helped to broaden the scope of topological methods for analyzing real (large and noisy) data. The development of the project further enhanced a synergy between computational methods, applied mathematics and data analysis. Graduate students involved in this project were co-advised by the PIs, and they acquired skills of developing effective and efficient computational methods based on, and justified by, mathematical (especially geometric and topological) ideas.
